WRITING.TEXT: If you don't mind loosing some background details, I would recommend you to set your aperture to f/4 or so, and also decrease shutter speed to 1/1000 or faster. Shallow depth of field should make drops pop out if focused right. But I'm not 100% sure, tested this with my 300mm lens on snowflakes, the result was awesome :)
Very good, and I really love the colors! Chromatic aberration is better be removed and I'd try focus stacking for this shot.
Not a real critique, but MOTHER OF GOD THE SIZE OF MEATBALL! Nice shot, good work with depth of field and lighting.

WRITING.TITLE: Need advice in composition and edit

WRITING.TEXT: I decided to shoot my wife and son in this place because I like the minimalistic feel of the image and how path goes across the valley. I cropped the sky out because there is a cemetery on the farthest side and it doesn't look pleasant. In general I like how it looks, but I have a strong feel that I am missing something. Shoot by Nikon 3300 + Nikkor 70-300.
Thank you for the reply. I'll try to crop the image and see how it feels then.
Wow! Never thought about cropping it that way! And I like how yo left the whole tree at the top! Thank you!

I am rather new in photography and lack editing skills. Some tasks just killing me, and here is one: I was not able to get closer to the bird or get another angle and now it blends with the tree. I want it to pop out somehow, but it looks like curves or channels doesn't help. I want to separate it from background without masking, is it possible in this shot?

Awesome shot and I really like the edit! I am quite new to photography and want to know how can you benefit from polarising filter here. I have one, but rarely use it. I only make clouds better with it and remove unwanted reflections. Want to know how it can be used in other ways.
I like the image, and how you processed it. But pink color looks a bit ill for a sunset, try adding more yellow.

Made this silhouette shot this evening and I really like it! Hand shape is not very attractive, but hope it doesn't ruin the photo :) The only edit was making shadows brighter. What can I do better here? Nikon D3300 + Nikkor 70-300 @300mm
Thank you for the detailed response! I brought shadows up because model color was close to the cloud and it was the way to increase contrast. This might caused the artifacts.
Many thanks, didn't noticed that hair is not good.

Nice shot, especially for the bad conditions you have mentioned, but I see some things you could do better: 1. Almost no sky here. I'm not a good photographer, but one should either include a meaningful amount of sky (e.g. 1/3 of the frame) in your photo, or focus at something and remove the sky completely. You have a thin line which doesn't look well. 2. Too much grain, even for ISO400. You might want to go down to ISO100 1/100, 35mm is short enough for that shutter speed. Generally you can shoot up to 1/focal_length without noticable shake. 3. Shadows are too dark for me. Trees and bushes seem to have details in it, but we cannot see it now. Try bringing shadows up a bit. 4. That shed stands out so much that it tends to be a focal point of the whole image. But it lacks details and hence not interesting at all. You might want to get closer so we can see what is inside or another attractive things there.
Nice angle, but lack of depth of field ruins the shot. I want to see more of this mud rift! While shooting with a phone you can try to use focus stacking technique here.

It was evening when we was sitting on the bench on promenade. Just before the sunset the sky turned red and I decided to take some shots. Here is the most interesting one. Shoot by Nikon 3300 + Nikkor 18-55
Thank you for the review! Haven't noticed that horizon is not level while editing, phone screen is too small for me :)

Took this shot after the rain from the rooftop. The sky was stunning and I had to make a photo! The problem is that sun went after the hill, but running to the open place would ruin that golden 5 minutes. The problem I cannot solve here is what to do with the hill? Leaving it almost black is at was before processing would throw away a good third of image while rising the shadows adds green color to a sunset photo, which, I believe, should be made within yellow-blue tones. I hope your opinions about this will help! Thank you in advance! Shoot with Nikon D3300 + Nikkor 18-55 (kit) @ 18mm f/8 ISO 100.

I made this shot during the morning walk on the beach. From this perspective it resembles Star Wars or Dune sceneries for me and I tried to postprocess it to increase that feeling. Shoot was taken with Nikon 3300 + Nikkor 70-300

First of all, nice shot! I would prefer horizon not intersect the bird and be at lower part of the rock, so that it is literally emerges from the water. On this kind of shots you usually don't choose where to shoot from. If you can visit this place again, try to make your way to the water and shoot from a lower position. But don't put yourself under risk! As we can see a lot of guano on the rock, birds sit there quite often and you will get another chance for a great shot. Also I support previous speaker, there are lack of space to the left and a lot of to the right - rule of thirds will fit perfectly here.

Right after the rain this bird jumps into small ponds of water inside big leaves. I found it so funny and also made several shots. This is my favourite. This shot have several technical flaws (bird is not perfectly sharp and there are a lot of chromatics that I cannot remove before returning from the trip). I kindly ask you to point on composition faults I could make here. Shoot by Nikon D3300 + Nikkor 70-300

Awesome! I want to have a skill to decide when to turn my shots b amp;w. You did it well, I like the edit. I see the problem in that pile of mud to the right. Looks like it pretends on filling the empty space, but when my eye drops on it, it leaves me frustrated. Try removing it for a stronger minimalistic feel.

I love the shapes of lightning, beautiful shot. I would crop it to remove a lot of unnecessary black space on the sides. Also clone out the annoying purple artifact, it is clearly visible if you zoom in to see the lightning in details. When lacking tripod, try to find any good surface to put camera on. On your shot I can see multiple lines coming along each other, this doesn't make it good. You did well holding camera for so long, but solid surface would do better. Even bag or a pile of straw is enough if you shoot with a delay of 2-5s which will eliminate any initial shake. Buy watch for your camera, it can fall during the process! :)

Took this picture of lily in the Phuket botanical garden. During the post-processing I removed bright reflections on the background leaving only dull ones, and enhanced color and sharpness slightly. What do you think about composition and edit? Is it overdone or the image is too dark? Shoot by Nikon D3300 + Nikkor 18-55

Good work, I like how it looks. But I have an idea that could make it even better. Now all the forest but the one tree is the big black spot. You could try to sit behind the tent and use flashlight to lighten the surrounding trees to make sorta halo of trees around it. I'm not 100% sure it would look better, but here is idea to try.

I like the left side of the image, but not the right. First off, the composition lacks balance with this huge empty space to the right and cut off buildings to the left. I feel a strong need to move a camera left when looking at the image. The second thing is the yellowish sky color in the bottom right part. It might be there when you made this shot, but try removing it in postprocessing, it looks ill. Anyway with all that I can see on the left side of the shot, you have great potential!

First of all, you should learn the basics of astro photography. Sadly I don't have a link on hand to share, but you can easily google it. Use the rule of 500: stars have trails on the shot. To eliminate this you have to set shutter speed no more than 500/focal_length seconds. Iirc you have 1.6x crop sensor, so for you it is 500/(18x1.6) ~ 15s. If you want a lot of stars, use higher ISO and stack shots, it's much easier than it sounds to be. And I don't like the abundance of trees in this shot, try moving away from it and you'll benefit from two things: there will be more sky with stars and tree movement on the wind will be less noticeable. Don't stop trying and you will get awesome results.

Awesome color and details! Please share your gear setup and how this shot was taken. It it the zoo or you shoot it in the wilds? If latter then where the hell on earth birds like this let you so close?

Took this shot while climbing the Aragats western summit. It's my first time shooting raw with GoPro 6, later edited it in PS. I decided to leave a slight fisheye effect to make it look more adventure-like (sorry for my English). Please let me know if something is wrong with this image :)

Hello! I see two issues with the shot. First, it lacks details that eye can stop upon. Silhouette is pretty weak - almost a line. You can try the same shot but from the closer point where the big tree on the 1/3 from the right takes a good chunk of the image. From here it looks like a solid candidates for this kind of shot. Next, you should do something to reduce the noise. IPhone 5 should have good camera (never used 5, but had 4 long time ago), I think there might be a mode where you set lower ISO and longer shutter speed. You will have to hold phone still or use any solid surface, but the shot will have better quality.

I caught the idea of this shot, but you can do better. Focal point of this shot is a plant in focus, so the blurry trunk on the foreground is just a distraction. Bend it with your hand so it is out of the frame. Next, the plant is curved to the left that makes viewer's eye go this way, but this it hits the end of the picture. Position your camera so that the plant is on the 1/3 from the right and it will look much better. Also 1/320 shutter speed is an overkill for that focal length. Even if you have cropped sensor, 1/80 would be enough for a sharp shot, just make several shots and choose the sharpest. It will let you bring ISO and hence the noise down. And the last, it might be a sense of taste, but I would shoot from a lower position to let the more leaves into the frame (they looks cool) and make the main plant on the bright background for more contrast.

Was walking in Sochi botanical garden and shooting random birds when I saw this! A gorgeous pelican cleaning it's feathers on a light spot in a shady woods. Had time to make a few shots before he moved towards the fence off the light (I was pecked by him later:)), this is the best one. I hope I haven't ruined it with processing. Any critique is welcome! Nikon d3300 + Nikkor 70-300

I was waiting till mid-autumn to make this kind of shot. But when I came to the place I wanted to make photo of, I realized that the forest green on the one half of the road because of coniferous trees! I really like how two sides of this shot adds up and want your comments on what could be done better here. Made this photo with DJI Phantom 3 standard.
